citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One of the male pigs is very thin with prominent ribs and vertebrae visible and hair loss on his tail. The licensee states
they have run a fecal with no parasites detected and the pig consumes a large quantity of food. Despite this, the pig is thin
and may have an underlying condition impacting his ability to put on and maintain weight. The thin condition of the animal
has not been reiterated in communicated to the veterinarian to further explore diagnosis or treatment options. This needs
to be addressed so the pig can be assessed by the veterinarian for his health and welfare.

The primary enclosure for the rabbit is not in good repair. The rabbit has chewed around the opening to the second side
of the enclosure and the chewed area has broken the seal on the pressed wood and flaked off white paint. This section of
the enclosure needs to be addressed to keep the enclosure in good repair for the safety and cleanliness of the rabbit.

*** There is a section of chain link fence that is not secured to the wood fence beams at the far end of the wallaby outdoor
enclosure. This is creating a large gap that could be a potential hazard to the wallaby if they put an appendage through
the opening. This gap needs to be addressed to keep the enclosure in good repair.
*** In the first pig stall, there is a section of laminate paneling that is cracked with sharp edges coming off the main wall.
This section of panel needs to be addressed to keep the stall in good repair for the safety of the pig and to facilitate
cleaning of the stall.
*** The shelter structure for the goats needs to be addressed. There are two corners of the building where the wood
covering the insulation does not connect. Insulation is exposed in both of these corners which can be a hazard if the goats
ingest the material.

At the time of the inspection the weather was approximately 44 deg F with 12 mph winds. The indoor stall housing the
juvenile single housed African crested porcupine did not have a wind break on the chute opening of the door and the
animal was against the interior wall burrowed under the hay and appeared to be shivering. The licensee stated they had
heat and a heat lamp on previously, but removed them last week when the temps went into the 80’s. Due to the coolness
of the ambient temperatures today and expected for the next week and the lack of a wind break, heat lamps should be
provided for the comfort of this animal.

There are no fans or methods of ventilation for the coati enclosure. This is large enclosure but the air was stagnant and
there was a chemical like, musty odor in the enclosure when the inspector was inside. There is wire mesh opening at the
top of the enclosure on one wall but this opening leads into an enclosed hallway that also contained stagnant musty air.
This enclosure should be adequately ventilated for the health of the animals.

The outdoor fox enclosure is not surrounded by a 6ft perimeter fence on the back side of the enclosure. There is a
perimeter fence along the front public side with a double door entry to prevent escapes. The facility states that they plan
to reapply for a variance that was approved in the past. If a variance is not requested and granted, then the facility must
ensure that there is a perimeter fence at a minimum of 6 feet around this outdoor enclosure per this subpart.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within (2 ) more inspection(s) or by July 19, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n
